Award.AwardTitle: Support for the Symposium on Architectures for Networking and Communications Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal aims to secure travel support for the seventh ACM/IEEE Symposium on
Architectures for Networking and Communications Systems (ANCS), which will be held in Brooklyn, NY (Oct. 3-4, 2011). Specifically, the PI?s interest is in providing travel support to ANCS for students. The ANCS conference has been created to provide a top tier venue to bring together researchers from the areas of computer systems architecture and networking systems, in order to foster greater collaboration between these increasingly related research areas.
It is proposed to offer up to 15 NSF-sponsored student travel grants for a total budget of $15,250. Applications will be solicited via email mailing lists, personal contacts, and the conference web site. The selection process will consider the applicant?s level of participation in ANCS, followed by how closely the student?s research interests match areas covered by ANCS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Student Travel Grant allowed supporting 16 graduate students to attend the 7th ACM/IEEE Symposium on Architectures for Networking and Communications Systems (ANCS) in Brooklyn, NY October 3-4, 2011.

The ANCS conference has been created to provide a top-tier venue to bring together researchers from the areas of computer systems architecture and networking systems, in order to foster greater collaboration between these increasingly related research areas. The ANCS 2011 program was organized in a single-track format and featured two keynote talks from industry leaders (Bill Lynch from Huawei Technologies and Dilma Da Silva from IBM T. J. Watson Research Center), 20 research presentations (selected from approximately 62 submissions), and two poster sessions including a total of 17 poster presentations. 

The student travel grant was publicized through the conference website and several mailing lists. Student from under-represented groups were encouraged to apply. To qualify, student applicants completed an application form indicating their institution, their academic position, their academic advisor, their reason for attending ANCS, as well as a description of how their research interests relate to the conference. The grantees were notified via e-mail about one week prior to the conference, and were allowed to register to the conference at a discounted rate.
